metadata.title: Journal Pre-proof Kidney Infarction in Patients With COVID-19 Kidney Infarction in Patients With COVID-19

abstract.text: the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2). Recent findings indicate an increased risk of acute kidney injury during COVID-19. The pathophysiological mechanisms leading to acute kidney injury in COVID-19 are unclear, but may include direct cytopathic effects of the virus on kidney tubular and endothelial cells, indirect damage caused by virus-induced cytokine release, and kidney hypoperfusion due to a restrictive fluid strategy. In this case-report we propose an additional pathophysiological mechanism. We describe two cases in which patients with COVID-19 developed a decrease in kidney function due to kidney infarction. These patients did not have atrial fibrillation. One of these patients was treated with therapeutic doses of low molecular weight heparin, whereafter no further deterioration of kidney function was observed. Our findings implicate that the differential diagnosis of acute kidney injury in COVID-19 patients should include kidney infarction, which may have important preventive and therapeutic implications.

body_text.text: Although diffuse alveolar damage and acute respiratory failure are the main features of COVID-19 infection, recent findings indicate an increased risk of acute kidney injury during the course of COVID-19 [1] [2] [3] . The pathophysiological mechanisms leading to acute kidney injury in COVID-19 are yet not fully elucidated, but may include direct cytopathic effects of the virus on kidney tubular and endothelial cells, indirect damage caused by virus-induced cytokine release or kidney hypoperfusion due to a restrictive fluid strategy [4] [5] [6] . In this casereport we propose an additional pathophysiological mechanism. We describe two cases of patients with COVID-19 that developed a decrease in kidney function due to kidney infarction.

A 62-year old man with a history of hypertension, Henoch-Schönlein glomerulonephritis (not biopsy proven) and a living-related kidney transplantation in 2016, presented with dry cough, fever, and worsening dyspnea during the last week. Maintenance immunosuppressive therapy consisted of mycophenolate mofetil 500 mg orally twice daily, tacrolimus (Advagraf 2 mg orally once daily) and prednisolone 5 mg orally once daily. His other medication consisted of metoprolol, losartan, barnidipine, hydrochlorothiazide, omeprazole and vitamin D. He did not take any anticoagulants. COVID-19 was diagnosed on March 26, 2020, based on a RT-PCR test that detected SARS-CoV-2 in a throat swab sample.

At presentation at the Queen Beatrix Hospital (Winterswijk, The Netherlands) the patient was tachypneic (respiratory rate 40/min) with an oxygen saturation of 89 %. His body temperature was 38.3 °C and the blood pressure was 121/73 mm Hg with a pulse rate of 59 beats per minute. There were no symptoms of emboli to the extremities. Laboratory findings were: Creactive protein (CRP) 7.0 mg/dL, leucocytes 5.4 *10 3 /μL, lymphocytes 0.8 * 10 3 /μL, serum LDH 290 U/L and serum creatinine 1.28 mg/dL. A chest X-ray showed bilateral

consolidations. An overview of demographic, clinical and laboratory findings is shown in Table 1 . Initial treatment was supportive with high flow oxygen therapy and tapering of immunosuppression. Thrombosis prophylaxis with dalteparin (2500 units daily) was prescribed.

On the ninth day after admission, the condition of the patient worsened. He became more tachypneic, his temperature rose to 38.6 °C. There were no episodes of hemodynamic instability and he did not experience abdominal pain, flank pain, nausea, vomiting, or worsening of previous arterial hypertension. He developed non-oliguric deterioration of kidney function, with a serum creatinine increase to 1.92 mg/dL and an LDH increase to 1145 U/L. CRP and leucocytes increased to 11.9 mg/dL and 19.9 * 10 3 /μL, respectively. Urinalysis demonstrated erythrocytes, and urinary sodium, creatinine and protein concentrations were 60 mEq/L, 45 mg/dL, and 37 mg/dL, respectively. The fractional excretion of sodium was 1.9%.
A CT-scan which was performed to rule out pulmonary embolism showed extensive consolidations and ground glass opacities on the pulmonary level, but no pulmonary emboli.

An unexpected finding were multiple wedge-shaped perfusion defects in the kidney allograft In the following period his condition slowly improved and at 20 days after admission, the patient was discharged. The mycophenolate was still on hold. At the time of discharge, serum LDH and serum creatinine had gradually decreased to levels of 560 U/L and 1.79 mg/dL, respectively.

A 58-year old male with a history of obstructive sleep apnea presented to the emergency ward with a two-week history of fever, cough, rhinorrhea, abdominal pain and increasing dyspnea. At presentation, the patient was tachypneic with an oxygen saturation of 90% with a non-rebreather mask with an oxygen flow rate of 15 liters per minute. His body temperature was 38.3 °C, blood pressure was 137/78 mm Hg with a pulse rate of 83 beats per minute. Laboratory findings were: CRP 33.4 mg/dL, leucocytes 17.9 * 10 3 /μL , lymphocytes 1.6 * 10 3 /μL, serum LDH 686 U/L and serum creatinine 0.89 mg/dL. A chest X-ray showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates.

He was admitted to intensive care of the University Medical Center Groningen (Groningen, the Netherlands) and was intubated the same day. A RT-PCR for SARS-CoV-2 was positive on a nasopharyngeal swab. Thrombosis prophylaxis with nadroparin was started (5700 units once daily). After two days he developed oliguria and deterioration of kidney function, with serum creatinine increasing from to 0.89 to 2.45 mg/dL, which increased to 7.99 mg/dL over the next two days. His serum LDH increased to 733 U/L. No sediment analysis was performed. Urinary sodium, creatinine and albumin concentration were 46 mEq/L, 111 mg/dL and 102 mg/dL, respectively. The fractional excretion of sodium was 1.5%. He did not have episodes of hemodynamic instability, new-onset hypertension, or atrial fibrillation in the period prior to acute kidney injury, but did develop cold feet and hands, with mottled skin and dry necrosis of three toes. Four days after admission anuria led to the initiation of continuous veno-venous hemofiltration. This treatment was complicated by frequent filter failure due to clotting necessitating the addition of systemic heparinization next to regular regional citrate anticoagulation targeting a therapeutic aPTT. At day ten after admission the patient developed a bloated abdomen with absence of bowel sounds. A CT-scan suggested bowel ischemia and revealed multiple wedge-shaped kidney infarctions, demonstrated in Figure 1C -D. One meter of small bowel with transmural ischemia was resected. Anti-cardiolipin and beta-2-glycoprotein 1 antibody levels were within normal limits. Anticoagulation was continued with nadroparin at a therapeutic dose with anti-factor Xa monitoring. In the following days, the patient showed gradual respiratory improvement and increasing diuresis. At day 28 after admission kidney replacement therapy was stopped, whereas the patient was still dependent on mechanical ventilation. At 45 days after admission the patient could be extubated. At 47 days after admission, he was discharged from the Intensive Care Unit and after 61 days he was discharged from our hospital to a rehabilitation center. At the time of discharge, serum LDH and serum creatinine had decreased to levels of 190 U/L and 1.18 mg/dL, respectively.

As knowledge on COVID-19 grows, studies are increasingly indicating that patients with COVID-19 are at risk of deep venous thrombosis and pulmonary embolisms 7, 8 . A recent case-report found multiple cerebral infarcts in three separate patients with COVID-19, suggesting that the risk for thrombotic events may not be limited to the venous system 9 We acknowledge that the kidney infarctions may not have been the sole cause of acute kidney injury in these patients. Direct cytopathic effects of SARS-CoV-2 on kidney tubular and endothelial cells due to kidney tropism have been suggested and were not excluded in our patients 13, 14 . Additionally, severely ill patients with COVID-19 may also be prone to other risk factors for acute kidney injury, including hemodynamic instability and drug toxicity.

However, both patients did not experience hemodynamic instability in the period prior to the development of acute kidney injury and the clear radiological evidence of kidney infarction makes it probable that the infarctions at least contributed to the loss of kidney function in both patients.
In conclusion, we demonstrated two cases of patients with COVID-19 who developed an acute decrease in kidney function and that had radiological signs of perfusion defects.
These data suggest that the differential diagnosis of acute kidney injury in COVID-19 patients should include kidney infarction, which may have important preventive and therapeutic implications.

Support: None. 2 eGFR was assessed using the CKD-EPI formula, based on serum creatinine. 3 Not measured on the day of kidney function deterioration, but 5 days later 4 Not measured on the day of kidney function deterioration, but 6 days earlier.

Note: Conversion factors for units: Hemoglobin in g/dL to mmol/L, x0.6206; lactate in mg/dL to mmol/L, x0.111; glucose in mg/dL to mmol/L, x0.0555; ionized calcium in mEq/L to mmol/L, x0.5; serum creatinine in mg/dL to μmol/L, x88.4; fibrinogen in mg/dL to μmol/L, x0.0294; urinary creatinine in mg/dL to μmol/L, x88.4.

BIBREF16.title: Computed tomography image in axial (C) and coronal (D) direction in the portal venous phase of patient 2 indicating a wedge-shaped perfusion defect dorsolateral in the interpolar area of the left kidney (arrows). Besides, multiple smaller perfusion defects were visible in the upper and lower poles of both kidneys

FIGREF0.text: kidney infarcts), demonstrated in Figure 1A-B. ECGs and physical examinations during admission had not shown atrial fibrillation. No signs of peripheral embolization of hand or feet were noted. Blood cultures were negative. Therapeutic low-molecular weight heparin (dalteparin 15,000 units based on monitoring anti-factor Xa levels) was started followed by acenocoumarol. Serum LDH and serum creatinine rose to maximum levels of 2130 U/L and 2.70 mg/dL, respectively.

FIGREF1.text: . Our findings are in line with this and suggest kidney infarction as a potential cause of COVID-19 associated acute kidney injury.The development of acute kidney injury despite hemodynamic stability in the presence of a mottled skin appearance and an increased LDH are possible clues pointing towards kidney infarction. No extrarenal evidence of thromboembolism was detected in case one except for a sharp rise in serum LDH levels. However, in case two, the patient did develop intestinal ischemia and digital necrosis, as an indication of arterial thromboembolic disease.Contrast-enhanced CT led to the diagnosis in both patients and is the diagnostic method of choice for the detection of kidney infarction as ultrasound of the kidneys has a much lower sensitivity10 . The logistic challenges of a CT scan for patients with COVID-19 on mechanical ventilation and the possible risks of administering contrast agents in patients with acute kidney injury are possible limitations. At the time of writing, the University Medical Center Groningen had 101 ICU admissions with COVID-19 of which 11 required renal replacement therapy, but since abdominal contrast-enhanced CT was not routinely performed, we are unable to make statements regarding the incidence of kidney infarction in COVID-19 patient with acute kidney injury at our hospitals.Thromboembolic events during COVID-19 appear to involve both the arterial and venous system[7][8][9] . However, the underlying mechanisms are currently largely unknown, but may include direct cytopathic effects of SARS-CoV-2 on endothelial cells leading to endothelial dysfunction 11 , pro-inflammatory cytokines stimulating tissue factor expression12 or the presence antiphospholipid antibodies leading to thrombotic events 9 . It should be noted that while we found large wedge-shaped arterial thrombi, there is also the possibility ofmicrothrombi, which may remain undetected by radiological examination. The possibility of microthrombus formation is supported by a recent post-mortem histopathological analysis of 26 patients with COVID-19, where segmental fibrin thrombus formation was found in the glomerular capillary loops of three of the patients 13 . The course in our patients suggests that initiation of anticoagulant treatment may have contributed to the improvement of kidney function in both patients and underscores the possible benefit of a timely diagnosis of kidney infarction in COVID-19 patients with acute kidney injury. In addition, increased dose prophylactic anticoagulation may merit consideration in this population.

FIGREF2.text: Disclosure: The authors declare that they have no relevant financial interests. Patient Protections: The authors declare that they have obtained consent from each patient reported in this article for publication of the information about him/her that appears within this Case Report. Peer Review: Received April 16, 2020. Evaluated by 3 external peer reviewers and a radiologist, with direct editorial input from the Education Editor and a Deputy Editor. Accepted in revised form May 23, 2020.
